Fish oil is added to baby formula for example. Some people need omegas for a variety of reasons. Some claim that high doses of Omegas help with attention and focus, hyperactivity, and all kinds of things generally associated with behavior. While I don't have personal experience with using omegas in that way, in a developing brain with issues, it makes some sense to supplement, though the expectations from just that one item seems insufficient just by itself.

If you're on Atkins or some other carb-limited diet, then your intake of foods that are grain-based or fortified with B-vitamins will be severely limited and a B-50 or B-100 supplement is indicated, as it would be on the Gluten-free diet.

If you are on a diet free of dairy, then you should take a vitamin D supplement. If you are allergic to fish and seafood, as I am, a compounding pharmacy can prepare a vitamin D supplement that is not fish-based.

If you have food allergies or don't eat certain foods by choice and have eliminated entire classes of foods, then you should speak with your doctor and regularly check for blood levels of certain things and supplement accordingly.

We no longer eat as our ancestors did. Some of us, for health reasons, are on special diets. It just all depends. Knowing the basics, preferably a bit more, about nutrition makes all the difference, in understanding what one's body might need over and above the food they eat daily.

It is easy to be critical of the views and perspectives of those with whom we often don't agree. But perhaps a more generous view is to applaud all who find redemption, value and insight in reading and study.

We need not all read the same works, nor even give approval to what others read. But in reading, we do elevate our minds by thinking along with the thoughts of others, the thinking of many great writers. The ultimate reading being that one gained, as our columnist notes, is through life’s experience.

There have been, so far, at least hundreds of thousands of climate refugees.  To ignore the deaths in heatwaves (Europe 2005, Russia not long ago), from floods (Pakistan, Haiyan), from fires, from droughts, and the rest, is heartless and wrong.  I don't have the energy to look it up, but will do so in the morning.  The claims here are counterfactual.

Susan, more people die of cold than of heat. E.g., in the UK, 31,000 people died of cold during the winter of 2012. We can save people from floods, fires, windstorms, etc. by taking specific actions. E.g., build better dikes, have effective fire prevention programs, build stronger buildings. Deaths from heat can best be prevented by air conditioning and ventilation.

In short, we should use our resources to help people by doing things that we know are effective.

Well, hundreds of thousands is not 50 million. So much for that prediction. Here's a prediction for you that is a sure bet: the human race will manage to create hundreds of million refugees through armed conflict in the next hundred years. We already have a good jump in the Mideast, Asia and Africa.

Four points:

1. The world is not going to cut CO2 emissions. Countries were unwilling to fulfill their Kyoto commitments, even though these commitments would have allowed total COs emissions to continue growing.

2. So far, climate change has been good for plant life, due to more CO2 and a longer growing season. The earth has more forested area. Food production keeps growing. (That's not to deny that more global warming might cause problems in the future.)

3. According to the IPCC, there's little evidence that climate change has caused an increase in natural catastrophes, other than heat waves. That conclusion is fairly obvious, because natural catastrophes (other than heat waves) have not increased. (That's not to deny that more global warming might cause problems in the future.)

4. In 2005, the United Nations Environment Programme predicted that climate change would create 50 million climate refugees by 2010. These people, it was said, would flee a range of disasters including sea level rise, increases in the numbers and severity of hurricanes, and disruption to food production. The actual number of climate change refugees by 2010 was zero.

Now 59, I grew up seeing some of these photos and many, many others. War photography and reporting was everywhere and it told a powerfully relentless story. Anytime you picked up a newspaper, a news magazine or an issue of LIFE or LOOK in a doctor's waiting room you often confronted the immediate reality of the war.

The pictures were powerful and the steady national diet was disturbing and ultimately political -- it was a kind of reverse propaganda that made many young people like me question the legitimacy of the war and the objectives we were supposedly fighting for.

Thank you for the story and photographs. I grew up in the 1960's as did most baby boomers. Reading this, looking at the photos, makes it all feel like it happened just yesterday. The images I remember. Some of the stories are familiar. The access that the press had during this war was incredible and literally brought everything home to us, this "living room" war.

We had done very well in material preparations for WW2. We had raised industrial mobilization to a well studied science. We did all that without a big military or massive production or a big budget for it.

We had a modern fighter for both the Navy (Wildcat) and the Army (P-40) with several more in the works including the early model Corsair. We had the B-17 bomber in service and the B-25 well on the way. We had the Washington class 16"-gunned battleships in service, and planned to take those Texas class out of service in 1941 -- the preceeding Arkansas was actually in the process of going to scrap when taken back because of the War. We had developed the reliable track systems and concepts that became the Sherman tank. We had developed and sealed the designs for our artillery. We had the world's best rifles and some of its best machine guns.

Between the Wars we had done very well applying the lessons of WW1 failures to be ready for mobilization if needed for what became WW2. We did that with staff colleges and design work, not a huge military machine and military industrial complex to feed it.

Bob, your defense of the church is not entirely inaccurate; indeed the affair with Gallileo has been milked for all it's been worth and more by people eager to find fault with the Roman Catholic church. This has always stuck me as misguided as the crimes against humanity committed by the church to this day are so vast as to make Gallileo's persecution seem barely worthy of notice, a dusty footnote in a gigantic compendium of violence and blood.

Gallileo's sin in this case was not his Copernican theory but rather his ridicule of former Cardinal Maffeo Barberini who had become Pope Urban VIII. Facts can be such a nuisance. As for Protestants burning witches...well, if we're going to do a head count, let it suffice to say that the centuries of torture and murder committed by the Inquisition stand unique in human history for sheer depravity; to break countless thousands of innocent men, women and children on the rack and then burn them to death for "heresy" (whatever that meant) defies understanding to this day.

there actually is data that actuaries can use right now to do their pricing. 100 years storms are now 10 years storms so, for example, the pricing of flood insurance along the New Jersey coast line has gone up dramatically. The effect of that pricing can cause people to take action which hopefully will do something to at least slow the pace of global warming. Of course you still have situations such as the legislature of South Carolina seeking to end global warming through legislative fiat or, alternatively, compel insurance companies to maintain rates which will lead to losses for the insurance companies. Those companies will then refuse to write policies in South Carolina and then what.

The point is insurance prices make people think about what is occurring and hopefully will result in action to prevent bad things from occurring.
